bibl.title: Essay: Lambert Breaks Quarantine, by [Paul L. Tate], [1954]

div1.p: [Tate] explains that Andrus was exceedingly ill and Lambert, in an act of bravery, broke quarantine to fetch Ames.

div1.head: Essay: Lambert Breaks Quarantine, by [Paul L. Tate], [1954]
div1.p:
Two practical nurses had just arrived at the Post Hospital.
tThey were yellow fever immunes. One named Lottie (I have
forgotten her last name) was sent down to assist Lambert.

Lambert told me about this afterward. He says he was get-
ting a long needed rest, when Lottie came and said there
was something wrong about the patient (Andrus),--He wanted
to be on his knees on the bed all the time.

Lambert went down and found him that way. He turned him
over but Andrus immediately resumed his strange position.
Lambert looked at the chart and found that the liquid in-
take exceeded the output, and asked the nurse if he had
been catherized. She knew nothing of such a thing! So,
Lambert catherized him, as it was a strict rule that in
these cases the urinal output should closely approximate
the intake of liquid. Then he left, thinking that was the
trouble.

Shortly afterward Lottie came again, saying the patient
was acting so strangely she did not know what to do. Lam-
bert saw Andrus was in a condition that he knew nothing
of, and that he must get relief or Major Reed might lose
his favorite patient and break the long record of cures.
Lambert, realizing the seriousness of this, decided to
do something which all his instinct and training tended
to keep him from doing--Break quararantine and get Doctor
Ames.

He crossed the railway ditch and across the parade ground
and finding Doctor Ames' quarters, entered and told Ames
the trouble. (Here a differance appears in Lambert's story
and that of Miss Winifred Lewis' account. I attach a pho-
✓ tostat of Miss Lewis' version.) Lambert said that The nurse
was not there, but came back from lunch and missing her
patient, bed and all, came running across the parade ground
after them, and that Ames reassured her.

Lambert and Hardy carried Ames to the pest house and he
found to be a carbuncle to be the cause of the trouble.
He lanced it and Lambert dressed it and they returned to
find a very stormy officer awaiting them. Captain Stark,
who used language that made Miss Lewis cringe. Lambert
went back, satissfied he had saved his case.

Personally, I know this happened. That day I was lying on
my bunk after lunch, when Hardy came in terribly excited.
He told me that after leaving the mess hall agfter lunch,
✓ Lambert had met him and said that Doctor Ames wanted him
to help carry him to the pest house, (we always used that
term). Said he had done so and when they had carried Ames
back, Captain Stark was waiting there and had used words
of denunciation he had never heard before. (Stark was a real
expert at that!) He was sure he was going to be court-maritialed
and discharged. He was a simple, literally minded fellow and
was all broken up over it. Asked me if when I went to the
Captain's office if I would let him know what they were going
to do to him. When I went to the office Captain Stark was
there, but never mentioned the matter. Of course Ames had
told Stark the necessity of the affair and assumed any blame
himself.

One who was not there and acquainted with the strict mili-
tary rules enforced can not appreciate the bravery of Lambert
in performing this act.
